messages.message:
Wanted to share difficulties I’ve had using solution builder as a non-technical user. When things aren’t working, I just assume the tool doesn’t work. In reality, the solution does work if you use the complex prompt option and add the proper context (thanks @Dan H).

Commenting with screenshots of my attempt to extract shipping address from the invoice:
• *Attempt 1*: this was from the suggested fields, completely incorrect, just a list of numbers 
• *Attempt 2*: Tried to create a new field for shipping address, AI Hub got some of it right, but included payment information in between street address and zip code. I got stuck on this part, I was looking for a way to correct the output and it didn’t seem like that was possible. 
• *Attempt 3*: complex prompt asking to extract the shipping address but not include payment information or vendor address. It would not have occurred to me to provide this level of specificity without the nudge from Dan
Hey @Will Brown, it would help me to know if you checked the docs. (If you didn’t, I won’t be hurt; technical writers already know users don’t want to read docs :slightly_smiling_face: )
like the documentation on how to use AI Hub?
I did not, I would assume the average user like me would not read documentation for this type of a problem, it’s too simple — I’m just trying to extract one field from a one page document
The big thing for me would be having some indicator or nudge here to attempt the complex prompt. An explanation of why the complex prompt option is even there
It says “allows you to write full sentence prompts” but doesn’t say why that’s valuable
Yep, I agree with you, @Will Brown, many users won’t go to the docs. Still, I have some thoughts about improving the docs based on your experience, so thank you.

@jean - In general, non-tech folk do not read documentation *nearly as much*.  I would assume something like this which represents the core/basic functionality should be solvable without reverting to the docs.

If the goal is that average people can use the product, we need to be realistic.  Average users will not think about documentation.  Particularly for base functionality.  Documentation should supplement for a-typical or complex use cases.  If you need to research how to do the core product, users will give up.

Yep @Dan H, we know that users, quite apart from technical level, don’t want to read docs. We always assume that a user reading docs is _already frustrated_. However, the docs should provide helpful information when they do go there, and that’s more what I was looking for.

Thanks for sharing that - and yes guilty as charged with never reading any documentation on any product I use….

I did navigate there, and noticed that it also lacks a description of _why_ the complex prompt might be useful (ie as a way to troubleshoot if the short phrase doesn’t work)
Like it would never occur to me to tell the tool specifically to EXCLUDE other data on the page

i think some of this is just enablement on how prompt engineering works, and not really specific to AI Hub… But I do think including that in the UI would be valuable for our less gifted users such as myself
even if it’s like a ‘did you like this result, Y/N’ button, and if the user selects ‘no,’ they are greeted with a pop up that says ‘try a complex prompt to improve the output’
